title: 107_hr3223
content: The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct these systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct water supply, delivery, and wastewater collection systems on the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It includes service connections to facilities in Dulce and the surrounding area, and individuals as part of the construction. The Act also requires the Secretary to enter into a self-determination contract with the Jicarilla Apache Nation upon their request. The Jicarilla Apache Nation has a contract under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems. The Bureau of Reclamation provides technical assistance and oversight for the project. The Jicarilla Apache Nation has a contract to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems under the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The Bureau of Reclamation provides technical assistance and oversight for the project, including establishing a process for the Nation to assume ownership and responsibility for the system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Act" referring to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, "BIA" as the Bureau of Indian Affairs, "irrigation" as the commercial application of water for agriculture, and "Reclamation" as the Bureau of Reclamation. The term "Reclamation" refers to the Bureau of Reclamation within the Department of the Interior. The term "Report" pertains to the report titled "Planning Report/Environmental Assessment, Water and Wastewater Improvements, Jicarilla Apache Nation, Dulce, New Mexico" completed in September 2001. The term "Reservation" denotes the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, including all lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico includes lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. A Rural Water Supply Project refers to a water supply and wastewater facility serving towns, communities, tribal reservations, and farmsteads in the area. The term "State" specifically refers to the State of New Mexico. The curr_chunk discusses definitions such as "State" referring to New Mexico, "Secretary" referring to the Secretary of the Interior, and "Tribe" referring to the Jicarilla Apache Nation. SEC. 4. JICARILLA APACHE RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply, delivery, and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. The project includes pumping and treatment facilities, distribution, collection, and treatment facilities, appurtenant buildings, access roads, and necessary property and property rights to serve the water and wastewater needs of the Reservation. The curr_chunk discusses the necessary facilities for water supply, economic development, public health, and environmental needs on the Reservation, including buildings, access roads, property rights, and other transmission facilities. Cost sharing is also mentioned. The curr_chunk discusses the tribal share of the cost for the Rural Water Supply Project, including design and construction costs for various water facilities. The Rural Water Supply Project includes water settling ponds, treatment plant, storage plants, transmission pipeline, and distribution pipelines. The Federal share of the project's cost covers all remaining costs identified in the Report. Operation and maintenance costs will be covered by the Federal government in accordance with the Indian Self-Determination Act. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will be responsible for its operation, maintenance, and replacement costs as per the Indian Self-Determination Act and the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan outlined in the Report. The Secretary has the authority to enter agreements and regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. Additionally, the Tribe will be responsible for operating, maintaining, and replacing the Rural Water Supply Project. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe must develop an operation, maintenance, and replacement plan to establish rates and fees for customers. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will select a construction manager for the Rural Water Supply Project. A memorandum of agreement will be entered into committing Reclamation and BIA to a transition plan for operations and maintenance during and after construction. The Secretary will oversee the construction of the Rural Water Supply Project with the Tribe and incorporate value engineering analysis. Technical assistance will be provided for planning, development, and construction, including operation and management training. The service area of the project will be defined. The Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation will be overseen by the Secretary in consultation with the Tribe. The project's service area will be within the Reservation boundaries and will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. Progress reports to Congress will be provided during construction. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will report to Congress on the planning, design, and construction of the Rural Water Supply Project. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States and cannot be transferred without an Act of Congress. Authorization of appropriations for the Rural Water Supply Project is granted. Authorization of $45,000,000 for the Rural Water Supply Project is granted, subject to completion of appraisal investigation and feasibility study by the Secretary and the Tribe. The Secretary and the Tribe must complete an appraisal investigation, feasibility study, and required plan before funds can be obligated for construction of the Rural Water Supply Project. Additionally, the National Environmental Policy Act requirements must be met before construction funds can be allocated. SEC. 8 prohibits the use of funds for irrigation purposes in the Rural Water Supply Project. SEC. 9 addresses water rights. The Jicarilla Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act (Public Law 102-441) adjudicates the Tribe's water rights under New Mexico State law. These rights provide sufficient water for the municipal water system, recognized depletions in the San Juan River basin, with no new depletions from the Rural Water Supply Project. Reclamation, in consultation with the Fish and Wildlife Service, has confirmed this. The Rural Water Supply Project will not impact endangered species or the water rights of the Jicarilla Apache Tribe.
